docs.lead_paragraph: In reaching an agreement that would cost them billions of dollars a year and poses the potential to chase away customers, cigarette companies calculated that they would still be left with sufficiently lucrative business that would not continue to be haunted by lawsuits that have depressed their stock prices, consumed ever more of their resources and given their industry an image as America's corporate rogue. The tobacco settlement announced yesterday would cost the highly profitable industry an average of $14.7 billion annually over the next 25 years, more than twice its profits from domestic cigarette sales in 1996. The industry called that and other terms of the deal a ''bitter pill.''

headline.main: Companies' Cost Would Be Great, But So Is Their Outlook for Profit

docs.abstract: Cigarette companies, in reaching agreement that would cost them billions of dollars a year and poses potential to chase away customers, calculate that they will still be left with sufficiently lucrative business that will continue to be haunted by lawsuits that have depressed their stock prices, consumed ever more of their resources and given their industry an image as America's corporate rogue; while settlement would cost industry average of $14.7 billion annually over next 25 years, more than twice its profits from domestic sales, outlook for profit remains optimistic (L)
docs.snippet: In reaching an agreement that would cost them billions of dollars a year and poses the potential to chase away customers, cigarette companies calculated that they would still be left with sufficiently lucrative business that would not continue to be...

docs.lead_paragraph: Historic Pact Proposed With Tobacco Industry Tobacco negotiators announced a settlement proposal that could forever change the way cigarettes are marketed in the United States, provide the states $368.5 billion in compensation and permanently alter the nation's legal, regulatory and public health landscape. But despite concessions from the cigarette makers, the proposal would allow the tobacco industry to win reprieve from the gravest legal and financial threats it has ever faced.

docs.lead_paragraph: There came a time when all the money had been made. Many committed suicide. The notes they left were all much alike. They had lived to make money, they said. Now that all the money had been made, there was nothing left to live for.
docs.abstract: Russell Baker Op-Ed column describes malaise that will set in when all the money has been made, and there is nothing left to live for (M)
docs.snippet: There came a time when all the money had been made. Many committed suicide. The notes they left were all much alike.    They had lived to make money, they said. Now that all the money had been made, there was nothing left to live for.

docs.lead_paragraph: The bipartisan shine on Senate efforts to revolutionize Medicare and protect its finances started tarnishing today, as the plan met pained silence from House Republicans and withering attacks from Democrats. On both sides of the Capitol, high-ranking Congressional aides said the central elements of the plan -- to raise the Medicare eligibility age to 67 from 65 and increase payments by the well-off elderly -- were unlikely to become law.

headline.main: HOUSE IS CRITICAL OF MEDICARE PLAN BY SENATE PANEL

docs.abstract: House Democrats and Republicans criticize Senate plan to revolutionize Medicare and protect its finances; predict that Senate will kill plan and spare them need to kill it in conference; high-ranking Congressional aides say central elements of plan--to raise Medicare eligibility age to 67 from 65 and increase payments by well-off elderly--are unlikely to become law; Sen Edward M Kennedy says idea that plan is needed to preserve Medicare for future generations is 'hogwash' (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Award for McDonald's In British Libel Suit The longest trial in British history ended with McDonald's winning a $96,000 judgment against two activists who helped distribute a pamphlet denouncing the company's practices. But the judge agreed with the claim of the activists that the company is cruel to animals, exploited children in its advertising and that its low wages tended to depress salaries in the fast-food industry. A1 British Tories Elect New Leader William Hague, an opponent of British membership in a European monetary union, became the leader of the Conservative Party after defeating Kenneth Clarke in the third round of balloting of the 164 Tory members of Parliament. Mr. Hague, 36, is the youngest person in over 200 years to lead the party. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: No sacrifice is too big for the Southern Baptists when it comes to their faith (''Baptist Leaders Urge a Boycott of Disney,'' front page, June 19). They are willing to banish a group of fictional, animated (Disney) characters from their lives to insure that a group of real, living people (gay men and lesbians) don't get health insurance. ALETA FENCEROY Sioux City, Iowa, June 19, 1997

docs.lead_paragraph: After a long day of horse-trading behind closed doors, the Senate Finance Committee approved a substantially changed tax-cutting bill tonight, dealing out victories and defeats to special interests and making concessions to members of both parties on their priority issues. The committee agreed to add $8 billion in new financing for children's health insurance by raising the tax on cigarettes by 20 cents a pack, nearly doubling the current Federal tax of 24 cents. The money is in addition to $16 billion for children's health care approved on Wednesday.

headline.main: Panel Seeks 20-Cent Rise in Cigarette Tax

docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee approves substantially changed tax-cutting bill, making concessions to members of both parties on their priority issues; agrees to add $8 billion in new financing for children's health insurance by raising tax on cigarettes by 20 cents a pack; committee yields to pressure from big airlines to reduce proposed tax on international flights; it agrees to make more moderate- and low-income families partly eligible for proposed $500-per-child credit even if they received earned-income tax credit (M)
docs.snippet: After a long day of horse-trading behind closed doors, the Senate Finance Committee approved a substantially changed tax-cutting bill tonight, dealing out victories and defeats to special interests and making concessions to members of both parties on...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your June 17 front-page article on the disagreement over whether the Federal Government or the states will decide how to spend $16 billion on health care for uninsured children mentions a problem facing lawmakers, namely, that if children are insured, employers may cut back coverage for the children of employees. This is a result of our piecemeal approach to health care insurance. What we need instead is the simple, clean, comprehensive solution with no loopholes: universal health care. JANE HIRSCH Pacific Palisades, Calif., June 18, 1997

headline.kicker: Don't Raise the Age for Medicare Eligibility

docs.abstract: Jane Hirsch letter says universal health care is only way to address problems of piecemeal approach to medical insurance for American children and adults

docs.lead_paragraph: On the eve of an economic summit meeting of eight nations in Denver, President Clinton chided critics of his free-trade policies in a speech in this suburb today and called on Congress to give him greater flexibility in negotiating trade agreements with Latin American countries like Argentina, Brazil and Chile. He also urged Congress not to revoke China's trading privileges with the United States, in a vote on its so-called most favored nation status that is scheduled for next week.

headline.main: In Denver for Economic Talks, Clinton Calls for Freer Trade

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton chides critics of his free-trade policies and calls on Congress to give him greater flexibility in negotiating trade agreements with Latin American countries; he urges Congress not to revoke China's trading privileges with US in vote on its most favored nation status; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee unanimously approved sweeping legislation today that would redesign Medicare and increase charges for affluent elderly people under the program, provide new money for health coverage of uninsured children and restore welfare benefits for more than a half-million legal immigrants. The bill would alter health and welfare programs touching almost all Americans. The changes in Medicare would be the biggest since its creation in 1965.

headline.main: MEDICARE REVAMP ADVANCES IN VOTE BY SENATE PANEL

docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee unanimously approves legislation that would redesign Medicare and increase charges for affluent elderly people under program, provide new money for health coverage of uninsured children and restore welfare benefits for over 500,000 legal immigrants; bill would alter health and welfare programs touching almost all Americans; changes in Medicare would be biggest since its creation in 1965; photo (M)
